channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sri Lankan President Has Agreed to Step Down, Officials Say
item.description: The news came after thousands of protesters, furious over his government’s inability to address crippling economic turmoil, descended on the capital and stormed his home.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators entering the residence of President Gotabaya Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka on Saturday, amid large protests over the country’s economic crisis.

item.title: Boris Johnson May Be Fading Out, but Not the Divisions He Stoked
item.description: Long after he is gone, his successors will be wrestling over his signature project, Brexit, and the insoluble issues it raised.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Johnson campaigning for Brexit in 2016.

item.title: Latest Japan Updates: As Nation Mourns, Questions Swirl Over Abe’s Security
item.description: Many people asked how a gunman was able to get close enough to Shinzo Abe to kill him. The former prime minister’s body was taken Saturday to his home in Tokyo.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Sanae Takaichi, right, who served in Shinzo Abe’s administration, was among the officials bowing as Mr. Abe’s body arrived at his home in Tokyo on Saturday.

item.title: ‘It’s Like Parallel Realities’: Rituals of Life and Death Blur in a Vibrant Ukrainian City
item.description: In Lviv, babies are born in a hospital just steps away from the military cemetery where Ukraine’s young soldiers are laid to rest.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Emile Ducke

item.title: Shinzo Abe, Japan’s Longest-Serving Prime Minister, Dies at 67
item.description: Mr. Abe was shot on Friday during a campaign event. Before he left office in 2020, he helped pull his country out of economic malaise but fell short of his most cherished goal: to normalize Japan’s military after decades of postwar pacifism.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:description: Shinzo Abe in 2019, during his second term as Japan’s prime minister.

item.title: Does Abe Shooting Reflect Success of Japan’s Gun Laws, Not Failure?
item.description: A crude weapon. Minimal security. One death. A closer look at the details of the assassination of Shinzo Abe may actually underscore the effectiveness of Japan’s restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:description: The homemade weapon used in the fatal attack on Shinzo Abe in Nara, Japan, shown during a news broadcast on Friday.

item.title: Blinken Tells China: ‘It’s Pretty Hard to Be Neutral’ on Ukraine
item.description: The secretary of state met with China’s foreign minister for five hours in Indonesia after a G20 meeting. In southern Ukraine, fighting intensified amid expectations of a possible offensive to retake occupied territory.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times

item.title: With Sign Language and Sound, an Artist Upends Audience Perceptions
item.description: Christine Sun Kim’s poetic and political art pushes viewers to consider the limits, and misunderstandings, that come with communication in any language, whether spoken or signed.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Russeth
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The artist Christine Sun Kim, whose work challenges viewers to reconsider how they hear and perceive the world.

item.title: In Canada, Rogers Network Disruption Prompts Outages
item.description: The outages affected customers of one of the country’s largest telecommunications companies. Some local police services said customers were unable to call 911.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: People outside a Starbucks in Toronto on Friday using its WiFi, which is provided by a different provider than Rogers, whose customers experienced widespread outages.

item.title: For Ukraine, Boris Johnson’s Resignation Means Loss of a Personal Ally
item.description: Boris Johnson may be a polarizing figure in Britain, but in Ukraine he is widely adored for his unstinting support since the conflict with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia

item.title: Russia’s Lavrov Is Pariah at Group of 20 Event, but Only for Some
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and other Western foreign ministers refused to meet with the Russian diplomat, but for many others it was business as usual.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, with Indonesia’s foreign minister, Retno Marsudi, at the meeting of G20 foreign ministers in Indonesia on Friday.

item.title: Boris Johnson’s Lies Worked for Years, Until They Didn’t
item.description: The British prime minister thought he could swagger and dissemble his way through any scandal, but found the rules of gravity applied after all.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.media:description: Boris Johnson staved off political extinction for years, swaggering his way through scandals on the strength of his prodigious political skills — a potent mix of charm, guile, ruthlessness, hubris, oratorical dexterity and rumpled Wodehousian bluster.

item.title: Why South Korea Can’t Quit Internet Explorer
item.description: Why a country known for blazing broadband and innovative devices remains tethered to a browser that most of the world abandoned long ago.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi and Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A tombstone in South Korea marks the final days of Internet Explorer. Microsoft shut down the web browser in June, but it is still needed for a small number of critical banking and government-related tasks in South Korea.

item.title: Brittney Griner Pleads Guilty to Drug Charges in Russian Court
item.description: “There was no intent,” the American basketball star told a Russian judge, as any resolution of the highly politicized case appeared to shift toward the diplomatic arena.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Ivan Nechepurenko and Tania Ganguli
item.media:description: Brittney Griner being escorted to a courtroom outside Moscow for her hearing on Thursday.

item.title: What Sparked the Protests in Sri Lanka?
item.description: Acute shortages have meant that medicines can’t be transported and fresh produce from farms can’t make it to cities.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sri Lanka’s government has asked Russia for help to import fuel into the country.

item.title: Ukraine Fires Its Ambassador to Germany After Controversial Remarks
item.description: Andriy Melnyk, an outspoken advocate for weapons for Ukraine, denied the role of a Ukrainian nationalist leader in the Holocaust, stoking outrage in Germany.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Andriy Melnyk, Ukraine’s ambassador to Germany, during an event commemorating the defeat of Nazi Germany in World War II at Berlin’s Soviet War Memorial in May.

item.title: Sri Lanka’s Prime Minister to Resign Amid Protests
item.description: Ranil Wickremesinghe, who had been in office only since May, said he would resign.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall
item.media:description: Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe in Colombo in May.

item.title: Who Are the Rajapaksas?
item.description: The Rajapaksas have dominated Sri Lanka’s politics for much of the past two decades, and in recent years, have increasingly run the island nation’s government as a family business.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: Mahinda Rajapaksa and his brother Gotabaya Rajapaksa, in Colombo, Sri Lanka, in 2019.

item.title: Sri Lanka’s Leader Will Resign, Ally Says, After Protesters Storm Residence
item.description: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa will step down on Wednesday, according to the speaker of Parliament, amid fury over the economic crisis.
item.dc:creator: Skandha Gunasekara and Mujib Mashal
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Protesters at the residence of President Gotabaya Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka in the capital, Colombo, on Saturday.

item.title: After Brutal Assassination of Shinzo Abe, Japan Mourns and Carries On
item.description: A day after former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s killing, Japan, where gun violence of any kind is rare, was just beginning to process the shock.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich, Daisuke Wakabayashi, Hikari Hida and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: A car believed to be carrying former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s body passed by onlookers near his residence in Tokyo on Saturday.

item.title: Luis Echeverría Alvarez, Former President of Mexico, Dies at 100
item.description: He had faced accusations that, as interior secretary, he was responsible for repressing protests before the 1968 Olympics that ended in a massacre.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Kandell
item.media:description: Luis Echeverría Alvarez in 1969 as he accepted his party’s nomination for president. He steered the country on a left-wing course, but his tenure was shadowed by his role in a massacre at the Olympic Games.

item.title: How Mexico’s Top Justice Became an Abortion Rights Champion
item.description: Influenced by feminists close to him, the chief of the country’s Supreme Court helped pave the way for decriminalization of the procedure.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:credit: Lisette Poole for The New York Times
item.media:description: Arturo Zaldívar Lelo de Larrea, chief justice of the Mexican Supreme Court. He said he believes that calling abortion murder “dilutes the humanity of women in virtue of a religious belief.”

item.title: Hong Kong Pilots Restore a Memory on Wheels: A Vintage Double-Decker Bus
item.description: When the pandemic cut their flight hours, two pilots spent months and hundreds of thousands of dollars reviving a vehicle that reminded them of a happier time in Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Louise Delmotte for The New York Times
item.media:description: Luca Tong behind the wheel of his “hot dog” bus on the Wan Chai harbour promenade in Hong Kong in June. Vintage buses of this variety have not picked up passengers on the streets of Hong Kong for a decade.

item.title: Behind Russia’s ‘Pause’ in Ukraine, Signs of a Troubled Effort to Regroup
item.description: The weapons and personnel Russia may be turning to, analysts say, suggest that Moscow’s next assault may not be as fierce as it promised.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Rescuers combed through debris at the site where residential buildings were destroyed by a missile strike in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: Blinken Presses China’s Top Diplomat on Ukraine
item.description: At a G20 meeting, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken sought to cool tensions with Beijing in an effort to further isolate Russia. He met resistance.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley, Steven Erlanger and Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Wang Yi of China, left, and Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken on the Indonesian resort island of Bali on Saturday.

item.title: Suspect in Abe’s Killing Will Be Handed Over to Prosecutors on Sunday, Police Say
item.description: Tetsuya Yamagami, 41, is accused of killing Shinzo Abe, Japan’s former prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi and Hisako Ueno
item.media:credit: The Asahi Shimbun via Getty Images
item.media:description: Police officers at the scene of Shinzo Abe’s killing in Nara, Japan.

item.title: President Defies Calls to Step Down, Despite Mounting Pressure
item.dc:creator: Skandha Gunasekara and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, second right, and Mahinda Rajapaksa, second left, in Kandy, Sri Lanka, in 2020.

item.title: Summer Travel, Made Easy
item.description: You need not travel far to experience the delights of summer.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Canada’s Slow and Troubled Path to Rapid Transit
item.description: Partnerships with the private sector were supposed to protect cities from cost overruns and delays. That hasn’t always worked out.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: After more than a decade of construction, a major intersection in Toronto remains a chasm from a light rail project.

item.title: Blinken presses his Chinese counterpart about the war.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, second from right, with China’s foreign minister, Wang Yi, before a meeting on the Indonesian resort island of Bali on Saturday.

item.title: Losing Luggage During Airline Travel? Here’s What To Do.
item.description: Surging air travel demand and airport staffing shortages have made this a bedeviling season when it comes to missing luggage. Here’s what to know if your bag doesn’t arrive when you do.
item.dc:creator: Julie Weed
item.media:description: Lost luggage is exacerbating summer travel woes. Above, rows of passenger luggage outside Terminal 2 at Heathrow Airport in London.

item.title: Ukraine and the Contest of Global Stamina
item.description: The conflict’s long-run trajectory seems increasingly likely to be shaped by whether the United States and its allies can maintain their military, political and financial commitments to holding off Russia.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destroyed cars in Irpin, Ukraine, this month. More than four months into the Russian invasion, the war has evolved into a battle of inches with no end in sight.

item.title: American’s Arrest in Russia Last year Resembles Brittney Griner Case
item.description: Marc Fogel, a teacher and former U.S. Embassy staff member, was convicted on charges of drug smuggling in Russia. He was sentenced to 14 years in prison.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Euan Ward

item.title: Abe was a transformational figure in Japan.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: As prime minister, Shinzo Abe edged Japan closer to the United States and most of its Pacific allies.

item.title: Questions Arise About Abe’s Security Protection After Assassination
item.description: Numerous videos show the gunman walking unobstructed past security before pointing a large handmade gun in the direction of the former prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi
item.media:description: Shinzo Abe, a Japanese former prime minister, in Nara, Japan, on Friday, minutes before he was shot.

item.title: The assassination shocked a nearly gun-free Japan.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi, Ben Dooley and Hikari Hida
item.media:description: At Shinzo Abe’s home in Tokyo on Saturday.

item.title: Biden Administration Signals Support for Controversial Alaska Oil Project
item.description: The administration issued an environmental review that represents a key step toward starting the Willow project. Opponents say drilling would violate Biden’s pledge to rein in fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: A ConocoPhillips test well in 2005 in the National Petroleum Reserve in Alaska.

item.title: A shocking crime with many unanswered questions.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:description: The man accused of killing Shinzo Abe, Tetsuya Yamagami, 41, was tackled after the shooting in Nara, Japan, on Friday.

item.title: Just Months After the Last Floods, It’s the ‘Same Thing Again’
item.description: The toll of recurring disasters is starting to show among the residents of New South Wales, with many desperate for a break from overflowing rivers and wildfires.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Loading a boat on the Hawkesbury River so supplies could be delivered to residents stranded by the floods in March.

item.title: Denali National Park Reinstates a Mask Mandate
item.description: As counties report elevated levels of transmission, national parks are once again requiring masks in gift shops, on tour buses and other indoor spaces.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:description: The Denali National Park and Preserve, in Alaska, in 2016. As of Friday, visitors to the park must wear masks in gift shops, on tour buses and other indoor spaces.

item.title: Shinzo Abe’s Influence Was Still Evident Long After He Left Office
item.description: Japan’s longest-serving prime minister became perhaps the most transformational politician in the country’s post-World War II history.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan, who was assassinated on Friday, edged the country closer to the United States and most of its Pacific allies.

item.title: As Russia Looms, a Ukrainian City’s Loyalties Divide
item.description: Most residents have fled the eastern city of Sloviansk before an expected Russian assault. About half of the 23,000 remaining are eager to welcome the invaders.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Mauricio Lima
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: Russia Votes to Shut Down Last U.N. Aid Route Into Syria
item.description: Millions of Syrians whose lives have already been shattered by more than a decade of war may be left without food, medicine and other supplies.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Refugees from Syria passing through the Bab al-Hawa crossing at the Turkish border into northwest Syria in 2019.

item.title: There is no sign of a Russian ‘pause’ for one Ukrainian town under fire.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Kamila Hrabchuk
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A resident of Bakhmut, Ukraine, surveyed the damage caused by a Russian rocket strike outside her home on Friday.

item.title: The U.S. May Be Losing the Fight Against Monkeypox, Scientists Say
item.description: Longstanding weaknesses in the public health system are giving the virus a chance to become entrenched.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Anastasiia Sapon for The New York Times
item.media:description: B, a medical writer in San Francisco, suspected monkeypox after a blister appeared on his wrist following a sexual encounter. It took nearly two weeks to confirm the case.

item.title: The U.S. will send another $400 million in military supplies to Ukraine, an official says.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Precision-guided shells for the American-made M777 155-millimeter howitzers are among the newest package of military supplies for Ukraine approved by President Biden on Friday.

item.title: Assassination of Shinzo Abe Shatters Image of Gun-Free Japan
item.description: Stringent rules on gun ownership had all but eradicated gun violence in the country.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi, Ben Dooley and Hikari Hida
item.media:description: Mourners at the site where former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe was shot in Nara, Japan, on Friday.

item.title: The attack scrambled campaign plans two days before Japan’s election.
item.description: For the time being, political parties across the spectrum are pulling back on their messaging, but the election is still going ahead.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley and Hikari Hida
item.media:description: Shinzo Abe campaigning with Keiichiro Asao, left, a Liberal Democratic Party candidate for the Upper House, in Yokohama on Wednesday.

item.title: Shinzo Abe tried to move Japan beyond postwar remorse and pacifism.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:description: Mr. Abe winning the leadership vote of his Liberal Democratic Party in 2018. He was Japan’s longest-serving prime minister.

item.title: High Court Sides With Prince Harry in Libel Claim
item.description: The initial ruling clears the way for Harry to pursue a libel claim against The Mail on Sunday over its reporting about his police protection.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:credit: Daniel Leal/Agence France-Presse, via Pool via Getty Images
item.media:description: Prince Harry in London last month. He has filed a libel claim against a British tabloid over its reporting about his dispute with the British government over his family’s police protection.

item.title: BA.4 and BA.5 Power Surge of Virus Cases in Europe, Officials Say
item.description: While many European countries have seen an uptick in hospitalizations, “what we’re not seeing is an increase in intensive care unit admissions, so the vaccines are still very much working,” an official with the World Health Organization said this week.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan, Isabella Kwai and Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cafe in Athens in May. While many European countries have seen an uptick in hospitalizations, “what we’re not seeing is an increase in intensive care unit admissions, so the vaccines are still very much working,” an official with the World Health Organization said this week.

item.title: Gunman Apparently Used an Improvised Firearm to Assassinate Shinzo Abe
item.description: Video shows a device consisting of two tubes, bound together side by side with black electrical tape, similar to a double-barrel shotgun.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay and C. J. Chivers
item.media:credit: The Asahi Shimbun, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A security officer chased after the suspect in Nara, Japan, on Friday. The improvised firearm is seen leaving his hands.

item.title: Russia Sentences a Lawmaker to Seven Years in Prison for Denouncing the War
item.description: The Russian authorities have opened dozens of similar cases since the government made denouncing the war a crime, but Aleksei Gorinov was the first to receive a substantial prison term for it.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Alina Lobzina
item.media:description: Aleksei Gorinov, a municipal deputy in Moscow, held a piece of paper that read, “Do you still need this war?” during a court hearing on Friday.

item.title: José Eduardo dos Santos, Longtime Angolan Ruler, Dies at 79
item.description: As Angola’s president for 38 years, Mr. dos Santos ended the country’s civil war. He also launched an economic boom, but it mainly benefited his family and friends.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell
item.category: Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola
item.media:description: José Eduardo dos Santos fought to end Portugal’s colonial rule of Angola and later became its president.

item.title: Boris Johnson Hasn’t Left, but the Jockeying to Replace Him Has Begun
item.description: The Conservative Party must decide not only who should succeed the scandal-tarred British prime minister, but also when he should go.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Boris Johnson after his resignation statement in Downing Street on Thursday. The process to choose his successor could last through the summer.

item.title: The Assassination of Shinzo Abe Rattles Japan
item.description: The violence shook the country’s sense of identity as a peaceful country where violent crime is rare. “This is so not Japanese.”
item.dc:creator: Hikari Hida and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: Mourners placed flowers outside Yamato-Saidaiji Station in Nara, Japan, on Friday evening, near where Mr. Abe was shot.

item.title: Biodiversity Crisis Affects Billions Who Rely on Wild Species, Researchers Say
item.description: The latest global assessment of the decline in plant and animal life found some bright spots but recommended significant changes to hunting and other practices to address the risks.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao
item.category: United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity
Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services
International Union for Conservation of Nature
item.media:description: Wild vicuña were herded into a corral for shearing in Puyo Puyo, Bolivia.

item.title: Everyday Violence
item.description: We look at where most of America’s gun violence happens.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez and Ashley Wu
